doc.after: There was a significant population increase during the 18th and 19th centuries, which the writer Esaias TegnÃ©r in 1833 attributed to "the peace, the smallpox vaccine, and the potatoes".[42] Between 1750 and 1850, the population in Sweden doubled. According to some scholars, mass emigration to America became the only way to prevent famine and rebellion; over 1% of the population emigrated annually during the 1880s.[43] Nevertheless, Sweden remained poor, retaining a nearly entirely agricultural economy even as Denmark and Western European countries began to industrialise.[43][44]
